========

The Immune Biomarker Study for Salivary Gland Carcinoma aims to investigate the immune response in patients with primary salivary gland cancer in the head and neck region and functional diseases of the nose or ear (patients indicated for functional ear surgery and rhinoplasty) without salivary gland tumor. Title: Three-arm Pragmatic Randomized Study on the Effectiveness, Feasibility, Acceptability, and Cost of Continuous Glucose Monitoring Devices Among People Living With Type 1 Diabetes

Overview: The study aims to:

* Evaluate the effectiveness of continuous and intermittent use of continuous glucose monitoring devices compared to standard of care among people living with type 1 diabetes.
* Assess the feasibility, acceptance, and cost of continuous glucose monitoring devices from a healthcare provider, recipient, and caregiver perspective.

Study design: The study uses a three-arm parallel-group, pragmatic randomized controlled design. There will be 6 study visits for all participants over a period of 15 months.

Population: People living with type 1 diabetes, children and adolescents with type 1 diabetes, and healthcare providers. Participants must meet specific inclusion criteria, such as having an HbA1c level of ≥10% within the last 3 months and attending diabetes care at one of the study clinics.

Interventions: 

* Arm 1: Continuous use of CGM devices for the duration of the intervention period (9 months).
* Arm 2: Intermittent use of CGM devices (2 weeks of CGM use each, 4 times) for the duration of the intervention period.
* Arm 3: Standard of care, which includes regular self-monitoring of blood glucose and insulin therapy.

Outcomes:

* Primary outcome: The magnitude of change in HbA1c levels before and after treatment in each arm.
* Secondary outcomes: Effects of CGM devices on glucose variability, hospitalizations related to diabetes complications, and quality of life among recipients and caregivers.
* Feasibility, acceptability, and cost of CGM devices will be assessed through surveys and interviews with participants and healthcare providers.

[/INST] The study is a clinical trial with the official title "Fractionated Stereotactic Ablative Body Radiotherapy (SBRT) With FOcal Dose Escalation on Dominant Lesion in Localized Prostate Cancer". The objective is to evaluate the safety and efficacy of treating prostate cancer with a combination of SBRT and an intensified focal boost using CTCAE v5.0 scale. The participants include histologically confirmed prostate cancer patients with cN0 and cM0 stage, intermediate to high-risk level according to NCCN 2023 criteria, IPSS ≤ 18, and visible dominant lesion on mpMRI. The intervention is a single group assignment that delivers a total of 36.25 Gy in five sessions of 7.25 Gy to the entire prostate with a focal boost, followed by five additional sessions of 50 Gy to the visible dominant lesion with additional urethra and bladder trigone sparing constrains. The primary outcome measures include biochemical progression-free survival over 3 years and local control with disappearance of suspicious images in the prostate on mpMRI after 12 months. Secondary outcome measures include adverse events such as acute urinary and rectal events, late urinary and rectal events, as well as assessment of patient reported outcomes. Both IPSS and Expanded Prostate Index Composite-26 will be used to evaluate the impact on quality of life.

[/INST] Flow and Grow - A CPAP Management Strategy for Extremely Low Birth Weight Infants: A Randomized, Prospective, Multi-center Study.

Objective: To determine the time point for maintaining CPAP in extremely low birth weight (ELBW) infants < 28 weeks GA, and to compare it to the current practice of weaning off CPAP at or beyond 34 weeks CGA.

Methodology: 

* Study design: Randomized controlled trial
* Eligibility criteria: Infants admitted to four Neonatal Intensive Care Units (NICUs) between 23 0/7 and 29 6/7 weeks gestational age, informed parental consent obtained, declining or unable to give informed consent, or any known congenital anomalies or complications requiring long-term support
* Study outcomes: Primary outcome is number of participants with CPAP/NIS weaning failure (i.e., needing more support and/or with increased sleep stimulation events), measured at 72 hours after weaning off of CPAP. Secondary outcomes include number of stimulation events per 24 hours, length of hospital stay, rate of bronchopulmonary dysplasia, use of postnatal steroids, use of antibiotics, number of participants with a need for re-intubation, total duration of positive pressure respiratory support, number of participants requiring supplemental oxygen, number of participants experiencing pulmonary air leaks, number of participants with nasal deformities, time to establish full tube feeds, time to establish full oral feeds, number of participants with nosocomial infections, number of participants with IVH grade III-IV and/or PVL and/or ventriculomegaly, number of participants with ROP, and rate of weight gain.

Conclusion: 

This study aimed to identify the optimal time point for maintaining CPAP in ELBW infants < 28 weeks GA, based on retrospective data and clinical practice. While the study did not provide definitive answers, it highlights the need for standardized weaning protocols and algorithms to improve outcomes for ELBW infants. Further research is needed to develop such protocols and algorithms, and to evaluate their effectiveness in reducing weaning failure rates and improving overall care for ELBW infants.

The study "Effectiveness of an Intervention Using Observation/Action Therapy Among Patients With Mild Cognitive Impairment" aims to investigate the effectiveness of action observation training (AOT) in improving cognitive status, functionality, activities of daily living (ADL), gait, and balance in patients with mild cognitive impairment (MCI). The study will compare a group that observes the therapist, a group that observes patients without cognitive impairment, and a control group with standard treatment. The AOT program will consist of exercises for the upper and lower limbs, focusing on strengthening, balance, and functional exercises to improve gait. The primary outcome measure will be changes in cognitive impairment, assessed using the Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MoCA). Secondary outcome measures will include changes in ADL, functionality, upper limb dexterity (measured by the Box and Block Test), balance (measured by the Berg Balance Scale), and gait (measured by the 10 Meters Walking Test). The study will be conducted at a center for elderly patients with visual or auditory impairments who are not able to carry out activities of daily living because of a lower limb problem, and have no other neurological or musculoskeletal pathology. The study will include 65 to 100 patients and will run for 5 weeks.

Study Overview:
This is a randomized, sham-controlled, prospective study evaluating the therapeutic efficacy of the Erbium:YAG laser in postpartum patients with episiotomy scars in respect of genital pelvic pain and scar tissue healing.

Keywords Provided by Centre Hospitalier Valida:
Episiotomy; Complications, Er-YAG Laser, Vulvodynia, Vulva Pain.

Official Title:
Therapeutic Efficacy of Erbium:YAG Laser in Postpartum Patients With Episiotomy Scars in Respect of Genital Pelvic Pain and Scar Tissue Healing: A Randomized Sham-Controlled Prospective Study.

Detailed Description:
Episiotomy is a planned surgical incision to the perineum and posterior wall of the vagina during the second stage of labor. The fibrotic and sclerotic scar tissue formed as part of the healing process of episiotomies may cause pain, leading to sexual dysfunction, chronic pain and infections, and scarring in long term. This study aims to evaluate the efficacy and safety of the Erbium:YAG laser in treating vulvar pain and improving scar tissue healing in postpartum patients with episiotomy scars.

Conditions:
The study includes participants who have given birth in the last 6 months with episiotomy, have vulvar pain and dyspareunia, and no history of connective tissue disease or other diseases that can cause vulvar pain.

Participation Criteria:
Participants must be adult females between the ages of 18 and older. They must have given birth in the last 6 months with episiotomy, have vulvar pain and dyspareunia, and no history of connective tissue disease or other diseases that can cause vulvar pain.

Intervention/Treatment:
The intervention in this study involves the use of the Fotona Dynamis Er:YAG Laser System in the treatment of vulvar pain and scar tissue healing in postpartum patients with episiotomy scars. The treatment is non-ablative, consisting of thermal-only Er:YAG laser treatment using R11 and PS03 handpieces.

Participants are randomized into two groups: the experimental group, which receives the Fotona Dynamis Er:YAG Laser System, and the sham comparator group, which receives the same procedure with a sham handpiece.

The primary outcome measures in this study are the rate of change of pain measured by visual analogue scale (0-10) and the efficacy and safety of scar tissue healing evaluated by USG Elastography for fibrosis. Secondary outcome measures include the rate of improvement in sexual function evaluated by Female Sexual Function Index, and the incidence and severity of device-related adverse events.

Arms and Interventions:

* Experimental: Fotona Dynamis Er:YAG Laser System Arm
* Sham Comparator: Fotona Dynamis Er:YAG Laser System with Sham Handpiece

The Fotona Dynamis Er:YAG Laser System is used in both arms of the study, with the experimental arm receiving the thermal-only Er:YAG laser treatment using R11 and PS03 handpieces, and the sham comparator arm receiving the same procedure with a sham handpiece. Each session consists of application of R11 handpiece to the episiotomy scar at Turbo3 Micro Short Pulse mode, with spot size of 2 mm, fluence of 9.5-10 j/cm2, frequency of 2 Hz and 4 pulses per point and 3 passes followed by PS03 handpiece at Basic Long Pulse mode, with spot size of 5 mm, energy of 800 mJ, frequency

[/INST] Study Title: Understanding Changes in the Gut Microbiome in Patients With Gallstone Disease and its Impact on Patient Outcomes

Objectives:

* To understand the profile of the gut microbiome in adult patients with gallstone disease
* To investigate the relationship of the gut microbiome with patient outcomes, including complications of gallstone disease and post-operative complications

Design and Methods:

* A prospective cohort study using electronic patient records, anthropometry, blood and imaging results, 3-day food diary card, and stool samples.
* Samples collected at diagnosis, 6-month intervals, and after cholecystectomy.

Eligibility Criteria:

* All adults aged >18 years, diagnosed with gallstone disease following confirmatory imaging at an East Kent University Foundation Trust Hospital
* No restrictions based on gender, ethnicity, or socio-economic background; pregnant women also eligible

Primary Outcome Measure:

* Bacterial DNA profile, to measure the diversity of species present in the stool of participants, through study completion up to 3 years from cholecystectomy.
* Other study measures: time to first complication, severity of complications, length of hospital stay, quality of life, and cost-effectiveness analysis.

* The study included adult sepsis patients between the ages of 18 and 90 who had data available for their first hospitalization and first ICU admission.
* Exclusion criteria included chronic liver disease, viral hepatitis, primary acute cholangiopathies, cholecystitis, hepatic infarction, liver necrosis, liver trauma, length of ICU stay less than 24 hours, and lack of simultaneous AST and PLT data in the first 24 hours after ICU admission.
* The study aimed to assess the association between elevated initial APRI value and the development of sepsis-associated liver dysfunction (SALD) in adult patients with sepsis during ICU stay.
* SALD was diagnosed by elevated transaminase levels or TBIL and was further divided into hypoxic hepatitis and sepsis-induced cholestasis based on TBIL levels.
* The study used association analysis to evaluate the correlation between APRI and the occurrence of SALD. They also validated the results using their own data.
* The primary outcome measure was the occurrence of SALD within 30 days after ICU admission. The secondary outcome measure was mortality at 30 days after ICU admission.

Title: A Randomized, Double-blind, Active-controlled Clinical Study Evaluating the Immunogenicity and Safety of Omicron BA.4/5-Delta Recombinant Novel Coronavirus Protein Vaccine (CHO Cells)

Participation Criteria: 

* Participants aged 18 years and above were eligible. 
* Participants must have completed the basic or booster immunization of a new coronavirus vaccine at least 6 months previously. 
* Participants could not have an allergic reaction to the vaccine. 
* Female participants of childbearing age and male participants who were using effective contraception were also eligible. 
* Participants with certain health conditions, such as malignant tumors or epilepsy, were ineligible. 
* Participants who had been infected with the new coronavirus within 3 months of the study were also ineligible. 

Study Design: 

* The study was randomized, placebo-controlled, and double-blind. 
* Participants were randomly assigned to receive two doses of the Omicron BA.4/5-Delta vaccine or the placebo. 
* Participants received the vaccine via intramuscular injection of the deltoid muscle. 

Study Outcomes: 

* The primary endpoints were the occurrence of adverse events and the immunogenic response to the Omicron BA.4/5-Delta vaccine. 
* The secondary endpoints included the geometric mean titer (GMT) of neutralizing antibodies against the prototype novel coronavirus strain, Omicron strain (BA.4/5, BF.7) after 2 doses of vaccine, positive conversion rate against the prototype Omicron variant (BA.4/5, BF.7) after 2 doses of study vaccine, and many more outcomes. 

Overall, the study aimed to evaluate the immunogenicity and safety of the Omicron BA.4/5-Delta strain recombinant novel coronavirus protein vaccine in people aged 18 years and above with different immunization programs.

[/INST] The proposed clinical trial is designed to develop and validate a noninvasive multimodal ultrasound-based biomarker for myofascial pain. The study will include 120 participants: 30 healthy volunteers and 90 participants with chronic low back pain. The aim is to use ultrasound imaging to diagnose myofascial pain and classify it into four categories: normal, MP without TPs, MP with latent TPs, and MP with active TPs, as well as to determine the presence of substantial MP. The primary outcome measures will be the diagnosis of these MP categories, and the secondary outcome measures will include the presence of substantial MP. The study will be conducted in three time frames with visits at weeks 1 and 2. The standardized clinical examinations will be used to classify the MP categories and determine the presence of substantial MP. The trial will use deep learning to integrate ultrasound measurements into a predictive biomarker for myofascial pain and test its ability to predict MP by using established validation methods.

[/INST] The Pain Intervention Via Video Optimization Trial is a two-arm, blinded, randomized, controlled study that will evaluate the efficacy of an adapted telehealth video intervention on pain recovery and opioid use at 3 months among opioid-naïve adult Emergency Department (ED) and urgent care patients with acute musculoskeletal pain. The study will enroll 200 patients and randomize them to either the intervention (video) or usual care (standard care provided by ED/urgent care provider and staff). The telehealth intervention consists of an interactive video given to the patient after an ED/urgent care visit that provides essential pain treatment information and encourages patients to discuss treatment options with their ED/urgent care provider. Data collection will occur for subjects in all arms of the study according to the schedule below: Baseline after the ED/urgent care visit via phone call interview 1 and 3 months after ED/urgent care discharge via phone call interview. The primary outcome measures will include pain severity and interference scores measured using the Brief Pain Inventory-short form (BPI-SF) at 3 discrete time periods (baseline, 1 month, and 3 months).

[/INST] The clinical trial aims to investigate the impact of Neuro-Linguistic Programming (NLP) on the academic performance of primary school students in Lebanon. The NLP program developed by three specialists will be implemented in the study, which includes 4 (45-minute) sessions for teachers and 2 (total of 6 sessions) for children.

The primary outcome measures of the study include the identification of school triggers through the "Identify School Triggers" questionnaire, the assessment of schoolchildren's strengths and difficulties progression through the Strengths and Difficulties Questionnaire, and the concentration, hyperactivity, and reasoning of schoolchildren through the Vanderbilt Assessment Scale.

The study is designed as a supportive care intervention, with triple masking. The study measures will be collected 2 months after the intervention.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that evaluates the effectiveness of using the ECOX teaching tool in the emergency department on OSCEs for medical students compared to standard learning during the training course. The study is designed to assess the value of the ECOX tool in improving the final grade for service ECOS and the control of psychological and student know-how prior to ECOS. The study includes two groups: a control group where students will use revision methods usually offered by the faculty or in the emergency department, and an intervention group where students will use the ECOX tool available in the emergency department to practice before taking the on-duty OSCEs. The primary outcome measure is the students' average score on the end-of-course OSCEs, while secondary outcome measures include average STAI-Y (State-Trait Anxiety) scores between the two groups and the average scores on the behavioral assessment during the service ECOS between the two groups. The study lasts for 10 weeks and includes data collected during this time frame.

[/INST] Summary:
The Effects of Pulmonary Hypertension Web-Based Health Care Program on Symptom Management, Social Support, Activity Tolerance, and Quality of Life in Patients With Pulmonary Hypertension.

Study Details:
The study is a randomized, parallel-group, double blind, and block randomization study to examine the effectiveness of the Pulmonary Hypertension Web-Based Care Program on the improvements of patients' social support, self-care ability, active tolerance, symptom distress, depression, anxiety and quality of life in patients with pulmonary hypertension. The intervention group receives a web-based health care program, while the control group receives usual care. The study measures the primary outcomes using the Pulmonary Arterial Hypertension Symptom Interference Scale, Multidimensional Scale of Perceived Social Support, and the 6 Minute walk test. Secondary outcomes include changes in quality of life using the Cambridge Pulmonary Hypertension Outcome Review.

[/INST] The trial aimed to assess the effects of long-term ventilation support on the quality of life of ALS patients and their families. The study compared patients who received long-term ventilation support with those who declined it, and included measures of quality of life such as the Quality of Life Scale, Severe Respiratory Insufficiency Questionnaire, Kidsscreen-27, and EQ-5D-5L. The trial findings showed that overall quality of life was better in patients who received long-term ventilation support, but the difference was not statistically significant. Additionally, there were no significant differences in health-related quality of life, disease-specific quality of life, and caregiver burden between the two groups. The study concluded that long-term ventilation support did not have a significant effect on the quality of life of ALS patients and their families.

[/INST] Neurologic Deficits and Recovery in Chronic Subdural Hematoma

Study Overview: 

Neurologic Deficits and Recovery in Chronic Subdural Hematoma is a single arm study using ECoG monitoring to assess for the presence or absence of spreading depolarization in patients undergoing standard of care surgical evacuation of cSDH. The primary outcome measure is postoperative neurologic deterioration, and secondary outcome measures include eGOS, MoCA, NIH toolbox cognitive battery, PROMIS 29 profile, and TBI QOL to measure neurologic and functional outcomes. The study participants must have chronic/subacute subdural hematoma deemed necessary for surgical evacuation, be able to consent or have LAR consent, and have a modified Rankin Scale score of less than or equal to 2. The study is open to participants aged 40 years and above of either sex and does not accept healthy volunteers.
The trial is designed as a single-group assignment study and includes a 1-5 day post-operative ECoG monitoring period. ECoG monitoring is performed to evaluate for spreading depolarization, which is suspected to play a role in neurologic deficits in subdural hematoma patients. The study follows participants for up to 180 days for long-term monitoring and testing.

The trial's primary outcome measure is neurologic deterioration, measured using the Markwalder grading scale or Glasgow coma scale by one point within the first 1-5 days post-operatively. Secondary outcome measures include eGOS, MoCA, NIH toolbox cognitive battery, PROMIS 29 profile, and TBI QOL to assess neurologic and functional outcomes at 30 days, 90 days, and 180 days after the procedure.

[/INST] The summary is for a multicenter randomized controlled non-inferiority trial. The study involves patients with active MS who have been undergoing treatment with ocrelizumab for 18 months and have not had a relapse in the past 18 months. The study aims to compare the efficacy of annual versus biannual infusions of ocrelizumab on freedom from radiological disease activity at two years. The study was a blinded, randomized controlled non-inferiority trial, and the primary outcome measure was the percentage of patients with no new or enlarged T2 lesion >3mm on cerebrospinal MRI at 24 months. The results of the study concluded that the annual infusions of ocrelizumab were not non-inferior to the biannual infusions in terms of freedom from radiological disease activity at two years.

[/INST] The SPARCOL Study is a randomized, parallel assignment study comparing the combined endoscopic laparoscopic surgery (CELS) with standard surgery for early-stage colon cancer in elderly frail patients. The study aims to measure patient-reported postoperative recovery and changes in exercise capacity, physical condition, and quality of life. The primary outcome measure is the change in patient-reported QoR-15 scores, measured repeatedly postoperatively. Secondary outcome measures include changes in exercise capacity and physical condition, EORTC C30 and CRC quality of life questionnaires, and a frailty questionnaire. The study also aims to assess long-term oncological outcomes such as disease-free survival, overall survival, and recurrence. In this study, the CELS procedure involves combining endoscopic and laparoscopic techniques for large local excisions of the colon with minimal surgical stress response.

[/INST] The clinical trial is a phase 2, open-label, randomized study designed to measure the effectiveness of nebulized 6% hypertonic saline in decreasing respiratory exacerbations in individuals with neuromuscular disease or neurodisability. The study includes two arms: experimental and placebo comparator. The primary outcome measure is the full course of antibiotics for respiratory infections prescribed for one event of respiratory infection, irrespective of the duration of the course. Secondary outcome measures include lung clearance index, forced oscillation technique, lung ultrasound, global LUS score, airway inflammation, and health-related quality of life. The study is being conducted by Center Hospitalier Valida.

[/INST] The study "Paraphilic Disorders and Other Conditions With Risk for Sexual Violence: a Case-control Study" is a clinical trial designed to study paraphilic disorders, sexual addiction, and parasomnias. The study includes both clinical and healthy control groups and will use a variety of measures, including self-report questionnaires and clinical assessments, to evaluate outcomes. The primary outcome measure is the Karolinska Interpersonal Violence Scale, which measures exposure to and use of violence. The study will be conducted over a period of 12 months, with follow-up at 3 and 6 months.

[/INST] The study aims to characterize how the metabolic parameter kᵢₒ*V differs in tumor versus normal brain and to assess the effectiveness of activity MRI (aMRI) as a metabolic imaging approach for assessing neurological disease in patients with gliomas.

1. Primary Objective: The study will assess the validity of aMRI as a metabolic imaging approach via direct comparison with a standard metabolic imaging approach (FDG-PET).
2. Secondary Objectives: The study will determine the utility of aMRI to differentially assess the metabolically active tumor periphery and necrotic core regions compared to FDG-PET (SUVmax). The study will also assess how the aMRI metabolic parameter kᵢₒ*V differs in the various normal appearing brain sub-regions. The study will compare how the aMRI metabolic parameter kᵢₒ*V within disease lesions change with different disease types, their disease stage, and their treatment status.
3. Outline: The study involves patients receiving a glucose tracer, contrast-enhanced MRI, and positron emission tomography (PET). The study aims to find the differences in aMRI metabolic parameter kᵢₒ*V in tumor versus normal brain, different normal appearing brain sub-regions, and the change in aMRI metabolic parameter kᵢₒ*V with disease types, disease stage, and treatment status.

Overall, the study aims to provide a basis for the integration of aMRI into metabolic imaging approaches for assessing neurological disease and to identify the potential utility of aMRI in the clinical setting.

[/INST] The GDMT Research, Education & Assist Trial for Heart Failure Care is a cluster randomized study that evaluates strategies to improve guideline-directed medical therapy (GDMT) in patients with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF). The study aims to compare the effectiveness of different interventions, including multiprong clinical decision support (CDS) with a patient portal message, interruptive advisory upon chart entry as a notification, and best practice advisory (BPA), as well as focused education. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of three arms: usual care, multiprong CDS with GDMT order set, or multiprong CDS with referral to integrated clinical pharmacist co-management. Secondary outcomes will include the percentage increase in prescriptions of new GDMT HF medication classes or upward dose titration of existing GDMT HF medications. The trial will also look to determine the independent and incremental benefits of education with other interventional approaches.

[/INST] The clinical trial compares the effectiveness of extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy (ESWL) versus ESWL combined with tamsulosin therapy in the clearance of upper ureteric stones in patients. The study includes patients with a single upper ureteric stone size ranging from 6-15 mm, history less than 6 months, and no previous unsuccessful ESWL or concomitant use of calcium channel blockers or alpha-adrenergic antagonists. Participants are randomly assigned to one of two intervention groups: ESWL alone or ESWL combined with tamsulosin therapy. The primary outcome measure is stone clearance, which will be assessed after 4 weeks.

[/INST] The Interventional Therapy of Tracheal Stenosis study measures the effectiveness of different interventions for tracheal stenosis that occur after percutaneous tracheotomy, specifically the rate of successful decannulation and the number of interventions required. The participants' ages are eligible for a minimum of 18 years old and all sexes are eligible. The primary outcome measure is the rate of successful decannulation up to discharge from inpatient treatment, while the secondary outcome measures include technical success, reintervention(s), type of intervention, clinical success, and additional treatment. The study is designed as a randomized controlled trial, with participants being randomized to receive one of three interventions: cyroablation, APC, or loop extraction.
